lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As Brent Staples points out (Editorial Observer, Nov. 17), the repudiation of colonizing freed slaves was one of the significant changes Abraham Lincoln made between the preliminary and the final Emancipation Proclamation. There was an even more crucial shift: the final Emancipation Proclamation provided for the enlistment of African-American men into the armed services. More than 180,000 black soldiers, many of them recently freed slaves, fought in the Civil War. Their participation helped pave the way for the adoption of the 15th Amendment, which proclaimed that the right to vote would not be denied ''on account of race, color or previous condition of servitude.''
abstract: Prof Louis P Masur letter comments on Brent Staples's November 17 Editorial Observer column on Emancipation Proclamation that freed slaves
